Jim Cakalic wrote:

>>> Thirdly: if it's not tested enough, then exposing the method and
>>> writing new tests is not duplication - in fact, it can significantly
>>> reduce duplication by removing the need to duplicate extraneous setup
>>> work.
>>    
>>
>
>3) I disagree. It's a symptom that TDD discipline is breaking down.
>Code has been written before a test that needed it. Now's the time to
>back away from the current implementation, write the test you /really/
>want, and then get to green. 
>  
>
Not necessarily true. Consider this: I'm using TDD. I write some tests 
and code in the usual cycle.

I now have a new feature I want to write a test for. I look at the code, 
notice that there is a private method that does that work - that's where 
the new code will go. I can write a perfectly adequate test focused on 
that private method alone - but I can't test private methods. So I 
refactor to extract the method to an appropriate class (possibly new). I 
run existing tests. I then write the test I _really_ want against the 
newly exposed public method.

That's the sort of thing _I_ mean when I say it's not tested enough: it 
means that there are tests I want to write which would be convenient to 
write if I can target them better.

I'll reuse my String-to-Calendar example. I want to do some work with a 
date, but I have a String. So I write a test that passes in the 
date-string, and sees that it the work is done. Then I want to do some 
error handling, so I write a test that passes in an invalid date-string, 
and I see the appropriate exception get passed out.

Now I want to handle the twenty five thousand different ways that users 
type in dates. I've already extracted the String-to-Calendar conversion 
to a method. Because I'm using whitebox testing, I know I don't have to 
test the earlier method with the twenty five thousand ways of entering a 
date - that would just be silly and result in a lot of extra test work. 
Instead, I take that method and I move it to a DateUtil class. I then 
write the tests for the tweny five thousand ways of entering a date 
against _that_ class instead. I would probably have also extracted a 
method with the same name as the earlier one, but with a Calendar 
argument instead of a String - I would probably make that method public 
on the same class.

This sort of work is exactly how I do my TDD work, and nearly always 
what I see when I look at a private method someone else wants to test.
